RESOLVED_ENTITIES.Supreme Court: Supreme Court of the United States
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.5th Cir: United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol: law enforcement agency involved in checkpoint stops and discovering undocumented aliens, with agents allowed to extend stops based on individualized suspicion or probable cause. Testified about how aliens or their families commonly pay smugglers indirectly. Conducts stops lasting approximately thirty to forty seconds to ask citizenship and travel questions and request consent for a search.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Government: prevailing party at the suppression hearing, with the right to request consent for extending checkpoint stop duration or to proceed based on probable cause. Required to produce canine records for in camera inspection by the district court.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: court where Raymond McMillon's case was heard, with the judge entering ends-of-justice findings before denying his motion to dismiss and before trial, received canine records and made docket orders. Ruled on Raymond McMillon's motion to suppress. Also the court that affirmed Raymond McMillon's conspiracy conviction. Clearly articulated its reasoning for denying Raymond McMillon's § 3B1.2 request at sentencing. Conducted a one-day jury trial. Considered threshold questions regarding standing to challenge searches. Made decisions on the speedy trial clock and granted continuances.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Raymond McMillon: co-defendant who accompanied Zeba Williams on a trip to Laredo and was present during the Border Patrol stop; raised issues on appeal including motion to suppress evidence, speedy trial grounds, sufficiency of evidence, and sentencing adjustments. Filed motions to suppress and for discovery of canine records. Challenged the sufficiency of the evidence on all three of his convictions. Identified by undocumented aliens as the person who motioned for them to hide in the tractor-trailer. Requested a mitigated role adjustment pursuant to § 3B1.2, which was denied due to his involvement being comparable to that of an average participant
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Zeba Williams: defendant who asked Raymond McMillon to accompany him on a trip to Laredo and was driving the tractor-trailer during the stop. Asked Raymond McMillon to ride along and help drive back from Laredo. Testified at sentencing, stating that he and Raymond McMillon entered into a joint partnership to smuggle aliens
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Luis Pena: Border Patrol Agent who initiated the stop of Zeba Williams' vehicle, questioned the defendants about their travel plans, discovered hidden undocumented aliens, and his actions were challenged as rendering Zeba Williams' consent involuntary. Testified at the suppression hearing and during the jury trial. Conducted a stop lasting approximately thirty to forty seconds to ask citizenship and travel questions and request consent for a search.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Manuel Hernandez: Border Patrol Agent who participated in the stop with his canine, Aroxa, and alerted to potential contraband in the tractor-trailer
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Luis Pena and Manuel Hernandez: agents involved in the arrest of Zeba Williams and Raymond McMillon, and the discovery of undocumented aliens hidden in the tractor-trailer. Testified at the suppression hearing and placed Zeba Williams and Raymond McMillon under arrest. Conducted a search that resulted in the discovery of ten undocumented aliens
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Supreme Court of the United States: recognized the constitutionality of suspicionless routine vehicle stops at immigration checkpoints for determining citizenship status. Also recognized the reasonableness requirement applies equally to checkpoint stops. Established guidelines for the permissible duration of such stops, including the time necessary to determine citizenship status and request consent to extend detention
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Speedy Trial Act: a statute that excludes certain periods of delay from the trial timeline, including delays resulting from pretrial motions and the time needed for a district court to assemble papers to dispose of a motion. Requires a district court to make 'ends-of-justice' findings on the record when granting continuances
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Bieganowski: a legal precedent regarding the timing of ends-of-justice findings in relation to the Speedy Trial Act, requiring that a district court enter on the record the necessary findings to support an ends-of-justice continuance
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court of Appeals for the F: appellate court that reviewed and affirmed the district court's decisions regarding Raymond McMillon's case
